Column: 405



    Head V -

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, this is not intended to be a controversial issue. This amendment is intended not to argue -

     The Chairman: Dr Lee, would you like to move your amendment first?

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Yes. Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head V of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    There are two amendments and I shall deal with them one after the other. As regards the Non-Constituency and Nominated Members of Parliament, I have said that this is not meant to be controversial at all. This amendment is intended not to argue the pros and cons of the issue but to inquire into what Government's intentions are on the matter. In fact, I have already told the Prime Minister that. The Constitution presently provides for a number of NCMPs and NMPs. Presently, we have one NCMP and two NMPs. One NCMP has been disqualified by Parliament under controversial circumstances. We would like to know what the policy of the Government is on these NCMPs and NMPs.

    As regards proportional representation, this amendment is also not intended that we should have proportional representation straightaway. As I have said during the debate on the President's Address, there is a need for electoral reform in Singapore. It must come some time or other. It might as well come sooner.

    If only 61% of votes allows the PAP to gain 80 out of 81 seats in Parliament, and 39% of votes allows the Opposition to win only one seat, then there is certainly something very, very wrong with our electoral system. As we know, the first-past-the-post system is no model of democratic procedure. It may even be said that it is one of the most unrepresentative electoral systems hitherto devised by our old colonial masters.

Column: 406



    A general election under this system could well produce a result which is the exact opposite of the intentions of the majority of the electorate. This has happened in Britain quite a few times. Any reasonable system of proportional representation would easily provide a more accurate reflection of the voters' intention in Parliament. In Singapore, the results of the 1988 elections, to quote that most recent example again, produced a most unrepresentative Parliament, ie, our present Parliament with its unjust, unequal and unfair representation. But I can understand why the PAP Government, with its huge majority in Parliament, is most unwilling to institute any change to this present first-past-the-post electoral system.

    If we should have proportional representation, then the PAP, even if it should continue to form the Government in future, will certainly find that it will no longer have such an overwhelming majority of seats in Parliament. But Government has its Vision 1999 and the Next Lap. And the PAP has repeatedly said that it sponsors an open government with participatory democracy in Singapore. That is progress. And this progress should also embrace progress in the promotion of justice and democracy in Singapore. Proportional representation would just fit into the bill. I do not intend to discuss the pros and cons. But it is my hope, and that of wide sections of our people in Singapore, that we have a just and fair representation in Parliament. Maybe the Prime Minister does not fully agree with me today. But I do hope that he will not reject electoral reform out of hand.

    Today, European countries all practise some form of proportional representation. Japan is seriously considering electoral reform. Prince Charles has also called for electoral reform in Britain. Since the former Prime Minister laughs, it must be a good thing. I believe that the least that the PAP Government can do is to form a committee to study the matter of electoral reform and make recommendations. Would our Prime Minister be prepared to do that?

Column: 407



     The Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Sir, in 1984, the Workers' Party rejected the proposal when we decided to introduce the NCMP scheme in Parliament. In 1988, the Workers' Party accepted two positions. In 1991, from Dr Lee's inquiry, I take it that he wants the Government to increase the number of NCMPs in Parliament. That is real progress.

    The Government intends to have more NCMPs after the next elections, at least four, and perhaps six.

    On his request to have electoral reform so that we can move to some form of proportional representation, I want to say here that I disagree with any suggestion that we should have proportional representation. The reason is this. If we have proportional representation, we are, in fact, concocting a brew that will blow up the multi-racial harmony in Singapore. Very quickly, political parties will be organised along narrow communal lines, even along linguistic lines and perhaps even also along religious lines. We are going to have a Malay-based party going for as high a percentage of the Malay votes as possible; a Chinese-educated party catering mainly to the Chinese-educated in Singapore; perhaps a Buddhist party catering to the Buddhists; a Christian-based party hoping to gain Christian votes; and an Indian party hoping to garner the Indian votes.

    Under that situation, you can imagine how politics in Singapore will become. Each party will campaign vigorously along linguistic, religious and racial lines and that is the perfect concoction to blow up the harmony which we have in Singapore. It is against the very concept of GRC whereby we try to force political parties to adopt a multi-racial approach in gaining voter support.

    We have, in fact, recognised the phenomenon mentioned by Dr Lee Siew-Choh and, that is, under the first-past-the-post system, the result could be that a party with 60-70% of the votes can win almost all the seats. It is because we recognise this phenomenon that we have introduced our concept of Non-constituency MP. If we have six NCMPs in Parliament, six out of 81

Column: 408

seats in Parliament will give us 7% of the total number of seats in Parliament. That is a fair representation for a party that could gain a seat in Parliament under the first-past-the-post system.

    No Commonwealth country has introduced the proportional representation system. Yes, some European countries have done so. But look at the result. Look at the result in Italy where they have proportional representation. Italy ends up with a weak government because many small parties can gain seats in Parliament and the result is a coalition of parties forming the government and the government on the whole has proven to be unstable over the years. We see them changing government almost every one year or two years. That is not the kind of system that we want for Singapore. If we end up in such a situation where government changes frequently because government comprises a coalition of parties, I do not think that will benefit Singapore at all.

    The point made by Dr Lee Siew-Choh has, in fact, been taken into account when we introduced the NCMP concept.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister's argument centres around two or three points, but they are all the same old arguments. The same old record is being played again and again. He talks about racial disharmony and a concoction of parties formed along religious lines. So far, this has never happened. The PAP has boasted that it could win in Geylang Serai, a Malay majority constituency. So what is there to worry about?

    The other worry that the Prime Minister now thinks about is an unstable government. Well, we need not have a total proportional representation all through. We could have it half-half. We could have a first-past-the-post system for half the number of seats and proportional representation for half the number of seats. Then that would allow us to have stable governments at all times. In European countries having PR although some have so-called unstable governments, there is no dissatisfaction about uneven and unequal representation. And that is what we want. We want justice.

Column: 409

We want to make sure that everybody's views will be represented in Parliament. At the present moment, as you can see, Sir, there is only one elected Opposition MP for nearly 40% of the opposition votes in the last elections. Surely under no stretch of the imagination would you say that this is fair representation of the votes and the views of the people in Singapore.

     The Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, we do not need to give 40% of the seats to the Opposition just because they won 40% of the votes in order for their views to be articulated in Parliament. One person from such a party will be sufficient to articulate all the views that need to be articulated over here.

    How would the proposal of half the number of seats based on the first-past-the-postm system and the other half of the seats based on proportional representation be superior to the system that we have, which is to elect a government in an election? The whole idea of having an election is for the people to decide decisively on a party to form the government. And under our system we make provision for those voters who do not see their candidates returned in Parliament to have a certain number of seats so that their views could be articulated over here.

    He has now shifted ground from the suggestion of a proportional representation to half-half, but this still does not solve the problem of parties being organised along racial lines, along religious lines, to win the other half of the seats. By compromising his proposal, he is in fact recognising that his proposal is a weak one.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not recognise it as a weak proposal at all. As I have said, I do not intend to argue this case today. If the Government should really be serious about the matter, let it form a committee and let the committee go into the matter and make recommendations accordingly.

    To answer the point which the Prime Minister has just made, that only one

Column: 410

Opposition MP is sufficient to speak for 40% of the voters, may I ask: do we need 80 out of 81 MPs to speak for 61% of the voters? Do we? Surely not. Maybe you need only two PAP MPs.

    He keeps on talking about parties organised on racial lines. I think we could devise means whereby it would be difficult for those people who want to canvass on racial lines not to be voted into Parliament if we have proportional representation. There are ways and means. Let them look into the matter and investigate. In fact, Japan is doing this very seriously. Let them study what is happening in Japan. They have gone to Japan. I have not, but I have read a little about it.

     The Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Sir, the matter has been looked into some years ago. That is how we ended up with the concept of the NCMP and also Nominated MPs. There is no need to have another electoral reform committee to look into it.

    The GRC is also an innovation to take into account the unique situation of Singapore, and there is no need whatsoever for us to have another committee to look into electoral reforms. We are clear that proportional representation is the wrong system for Singapore.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Sir, true, the Prime Minister has said something about the matter some years ago. Well, we are progressing. We are now in 1991, and the PAP now talks about 1999. So, why do we not improve on the past? Certainly this is time for change.

     The Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Opposition MP, Dr Lee Siew-Choh, can come up with a superior idea, we will certainly consider it. But his proposal is far from superior.

     The Chairman: Dr Lee, are you withdrawing your amendment?

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: I am not withdrawing, Sir. I still hope that Government will consider the matter and form a committee to go into this matter more seriously. Call Prof. Tommy Koh to do that.

    Head K -

     The Chairman: Head K - Ministry of Defence. Amendment No. (1), we have 40 minutes, Mr Ng Pock Too.

     Mr Ng Pock Too (Nee Soon Central): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head K of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, many instructive lessons can be learnt from the six months Gulf War. First, no one can assume that the world today will always remain a community of peace-loving nations. For the naive, there can be deadly surprises behind the facade of warm words like cooperation and co-existence. Regional and world peace can never be taken for granted, even though global tensions have eased. With the withdrawal of US presence as a stabilising force from many regions in the world and hence a reduced commitment to world security, potential conflicts among regional powers can suddenly erupt. We must remember that for a small nation like Singapore, our security depends on the stability of the region and in the world. Without global stability and respect for international law and order by the world community, our economic progress will falter.

    Second, in the last resort we are on our own. We can only rely on ourselves to protect and defend Singapore. We cannot pay others to defend us. Without a strong defence capability of our own, we can end up like Kuwait on 2nd August 1990. The most excruciating scene I have witnessed recently was the statement made by the Kuwaiti Ambassador to the United States who was interviewed on CNN. The interviewer had asked him whether he regretted the action by the US in supplying arms to Iraq in its war with Iran and which were now used to invade and occupy Kuwait.

Column: 412

The Ambassador put it this way. He had double regrets, because Kuwait had paid for the supplies of military equipment thinking that Iraq would defend her in any conflict with Iran.

    Third, technical superiority of equipment and proper defence training are crucial determinants in giving us the ability to defend ourselves in modern warfare. We saw this vividly on CNN. This means heavy expenditure on high technology defence equipment to run an effective army, navy and air force capable of defending Singapore against external threats.

    Fourth, the good life which we enjoy through sustained economic progress can make us complacent and lower our guard, so much so that we run the danger of taking the soft options when we face a crisis. This is particularly relevant to reservists who sometimes question the need for serious defence training and mobilisation exercises for which they were called up when there are no visible external threats.

    Before the invasion, Kuwait did not perceive Iraq as a military threat. It was totally unprepared for any external incursion. When it realised that 100,000 Iraqi troops supported by 350 tanks and heavy artillery had overrun the border, Kuwaiti resistance was too little and too late. As a nation enfeebled by the easy life, Kuwait paid an enormous price in terms of loss of lives of its people, permanent damage to its social fabric, devastation of its infrastructure and looted of its national wealth.

    This brings me to the Report of the Committee to Recognise the Contributions of Reservists to Total Defence (RECORD). In my view, the key sentence in the Report is to be found in BG George Yeo's letter to the Deputy Prime Minister. And I quote:

    '... we thought it most important that in addition to recommending ways to recognise the contribution of reservists, we also recommend ways to enhance the contribution by reservists to Total Defence'.

    In other words, recognition through rewards must go hand in hand with contribution. The more a reservist contributes, the more he gains in terms of rewards. From past

Column: 413

experience in the SAF, a reservist who excels in his unit normally ends up shouldering more than his fair share of responsibility. This is unfair. So the principle of positive discrimination will differentiate those who contribute more from those who contribute less.

    While I agree with the principle of positive discrimination, I must, however, alert RECORD to the dangers of over-emphasising material incentives to motivate reservists. There must be a proper balance struck between reward and commitment. And unless our reservists possess the will and commitment to defend Singapore with their lives, they will melt away in the heat of a crisis.

    This draws an interesting parallel to NTUC's experience of increasing their union membership. In 1985, alarmed by a rapid decline in union membership, NTUC undertook an indepth analysis into the factors that led to the drastic drop in union members. It made the recommendation, firstly, that it had to exercise positive discrimination to differentiate union from non-union members and, secondly, that it had to provide a range of tangible union benefits to be enjoyed only by members while ensuring that it did not lose sight of its objective for which it was set up to accomplish - the protection of workers' rights. This led to the provision of benefits in the form of NTUC Club membership, discounts for purchases at various departmental stores, and now golf club memberships. SAFRA is approaching the problem the same way.

    So, in recognising the contribution of reservists, we must never lose sight of the SAF's mission. It is to defend Singapore through the commitment of our citizens and in particular our reservist soldiers. President John F. Kennedy once said: Ask not what your country can do for you but ask what you can do for your country. In Singapore, I would put it this way: Ask what you can do for your country; but also ask what your country can do for you. The right balance of commitment and reward has to be found.

Column: 414


1.00 pm

    Over the past few years, the SAF has increasingly undertaken humanitarian missions in countries which have asked for our assistance. For instance, a SAF medical team was in the Philippines in July 1990 to render medical assistance to casualties from a serious earthquake disaster. In August 1990, a combined Singapore and Bruneian evacuation team went on a rescue mission to Jordan to ferry Sri Lankan refugees affected by the Gulf War. And most recently, the SAF medical team was sent on a humanitarian mission to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, to treat war casualties of all nationalities in the Gulf War. I might also add here that the Singapore Police Force also sent a team to Namibia last year to supervise the election in the country under the United Nations transitional assistance programme.

    Such missions are not holiday trips for our men. They are exposed to dangers and risks of death and injury. Their lives are on the line. In view of the likelihood that we may be involved in many more such missions in the future, I would like to ask the Minister whether those sent on such missions are volunteers or are they chosen by a set of criteria. Can the SAF respond to more similar requests by nations affected by unfortunate natural disasters or national crises?

    The common thread that runs through the three issues I have raised is voluntarism. It is this core value that commits one's life to the nation over one's own material well-being. Placing nation before self gives the will to fight to survive when threatened. The majority of Singaporeans understand the survival imperatives. They will have to convince the minority who mistakenly think that the responsibility to defend the nation should be done by those other than themselves. RECORD will do justice to those who care for our national survival.

    Sir, my GPC members will elaborate in greater detail on these three issues I have raised.

Column: 415



     Mr Lew Syn Pau (Tanglin): Sir, first of all, let me declare my interest as a reservist.

    Last year, at the debate on the same topic in the Committee of Supply, the general sentiment among MPs who spoke was that there was not enough recognition given to reservists who sacrificed time, family life, and sometimes, career and business setbacks during the three to six weeks of reservist raining every year. In addition to the inconvenience of being away from the office during reservist training, there are other inconveniences outside the training period which they encountered, such as mobilization and the one year validity for their passports. In positive response, the then Second Minister for Defence, BG Lee Hsien, Loong, announced that MINDEF would extend the validity of their passports from one year to two years with effect from 1st June 1990, when the Immigration Department computerised immigration procedures. He also said, "If the new system works well, and reservists keep their units posted of their whereabouts when they go overseas, then MINDEF will review the passport validity to see if it can be extended further." I would like to ask the Minister how the computerised immigration procedures have fared so far, and whether MINDEF will consider extending the validity of reservists' passports to 10 years, the same as for non-reservists.

    Last year, the Second Minister for Defence also announced the formation of a Committee chaired by BG George Yeo to study and recommend ways to recognise and reward the contributions of reservists. Today, the report of RECORD has been released. I would like to congratulate the Committee for a job well done. The recommendations are comprehensive, bold and innovative. In fact, much more than what I would have dared to ask as a reservist without appearing too mercenary.

    I support the two underlying principles of the recommendations, that is, firstly, we must recognise the contributions of reservists in general, and recognise more those who contribute more; and secondly, in recognising reservists we should not unwitt-

Column: 416

ingly discourage the immigration of foreign talents into Singapore. In this respect, therefore, I support the case for a slightly more favourable income tax rate of, say, 1 to 2 percentage points for citizens as opposed to non-citizens. We should emphasise that citizenship has its privileges, not just obligations of National Service.

    As for the in-camp training allowance over and above the rank pay and make-up pay, personally, I do not think it is necessary, although it would be a bonus to have it. More important to the reservist than in-camp training allowance are the support of the employer and the understanding of his reservist commanders. When a reservist goes for reservist training, he worries about the outstanding work in his office and whether his boss will penalise him for any delays or other setbacks that may subsequently affect his promotion. At the same time, he worries about the transition from civilian to army green and whether his reservist commanders will make it difficult for him to make that transition. Employers and reservist commanders can make reservist training either a chore to be dreaded, or a welcome change from the office. MINDEF, therefore, should spend more resources educating employers and reservist commanders.

    I am also happy to note that the Government will build a Country Club for reservists. I support the concept of term membership rather than transferable membership for active reservists. In this way, the scheme will not deny further generations of reservists access to the Club. I would like to ask the Minister when the Club will be ready for use by reservists and their families.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun (Hong Kah GRC): Sir, let me first declare that I am a reservist and also a member of the RECORD Committee which has recently submitted to MINDEF its recommendations for recognising the contribution of reservists to Total Defence.

    Sir, yesterday I spoke about the need to have a preferential tax rate for citizens. This is one of the key recommendations by

Column: 417

RECORD. I am glad to know that the Minister for Finance is now considering it and I hope to hear good news from him.

    To many reservists, however, preferential tax rate for citizens represents a general and broad recognition for the role of citizens. While they welcome such a recognition, they feel that it should not stand alone and should be only the first tier of a multi-tier structure of benefits. For those who shoulder a heavier reservist burden, more recognition should be given. Otherwise, it will be difficult to motivate reservists to perform their best and take on heavier responsibilities after that.

    Sir, the recommended In-Camp Training (ICT) allowance for reservists as a second-tier financial recognition should therefore be seen in this light. Many reservists will argue that the ICT allowance is even more important and meaningful and should also be given through the tax mechanism. This will send a strong and effective signal to all reservists of the public recognition accorded them for their annual contribution to the security of the nation.
